settings.title: Acid Reflux Treatment and Medicine
settings.subtitle: Acid Reflux is an uncomfortable burning feeling in the chest that is caused by stomach acid travelling up towards the throat. We have a range of medications that treat acid reflux.

settings.title: What causes acid reflux?
settings.text: Some foods may cause acid reflux, these include high-fat foods (fried or fast foods), citrus, tomatoes, onions, coffee, mint and soda. Other conditions such as anxiety, asthma, IBS or even pregnancy, are also thought to be linked to acid reflux. A high alcohol consumption has also been linked to a higher likelihood of acid reflux.

settings.title: What can I do to help my acid reflux?
settings.text: Acid reflux happens when the lower esophageal sphincter (LES) doesn't close or tighten properly after you swallow. To lessen the likelihood of acid reflux, you can lessen the number of large meals you eat frequently, and avoid lying down soon after you've finished eating.

settings.title: of people in the UK suffer from an acid reflux disease
settings.text: According to the Springfield Hospital, one in five people in the UK suffer from acid reflux with many saying it significantly impacts their day-to-day life.

settings.title: of people in the UK suffer from regular heartburn
settings.text: According to Action Against Heartburn.org, 30-40% of the UK population experience heartburn regularly.

settings.title: Acid Reflux Treatment Explained
settings.text: "Acid reflux occurs when excess stomach acid is climbing up into your oesophagus (food pipe). This can cause mixed symptoms, including heartburn, chest pain, and regurgitation. Too much acid reflux can lead to gastroesophageal reflux disease or GORD. This disease is a common problem affecting millions worldwide and is becoming more common in developed countries."

settings.title: What treatment can I use for acid reflux?
settings.text: Treatment for heartburn involves a proton pump inhibitor which reduces the amount of acid your stomach makes.

settings.title: What can I drink when I have acid reflux?
settings.text: There are certain drinks that could help with acid reflux, these can include water, unsweetened coconut water, ginger tea, plant-based milks and certain fruit or vegetable juices.

settings.title: What foods should I avoid if I have acid reflux?
settings.text:
For those with acid reflux, the foods to avoid can include:

High-fat foods,

Tomatoes and citrus fruit,

Garlic and onions,

Spicy foods,

Fried and fast food

Cheese

Chocolate

settings.title: How can I get rid of acid reflux fast?
settings.text: Aside from medication and avoiding foods, to get rid of acid reflux you can try a licorice supplement, apple cider vinegar in water, chewing gum and trying to add ginger to food and drinks.
